title: Literature Assessment Anchors and Eligible Content: ELA
subject: Keystone Exams (2014-)

document.title: Keystone Exams: Literature Assessment Anchors and Eligible Content

BB219FE531B44F81B2EC5E315FD73FAA.description:
Explain, interpret, describe, and/or analyze the
author’s defense of a claim to make a point or
construct an argument in nonfictional text.

1F162218FF7E43B39D59BCFECF403A2A.description:
Explain, describe, and/or analyze the effectiveness
of bias (explicit and implicit) and propaganda
techniques in nonfictional text.

76DF88D67B4D4E6CB85F87E64626A3A9.description:
Identify, explain, and/or interpret bias and
propaganda techniques in nonfictional text.

4D927ADBA0A74D4DAE529CAE407C84DE.description:
Explain, interpret, describe, and/or analyze the use
of facts and opinions in a text.

47DE1404F38F4550A8FB8A4831BBD1CD.description:
Use appropriate strategies to
identify and analyze essential and
nonessential information in
literary nonfiction.

3C3EAA6C6E754C4D80F4CF7C7759CDFF.description:
Analyze and evaluate how graphics and charts
clarify, simplify, and organize complex
informational texts.

26FE65391BA546B7975AB5025B585E8B.description:
Make connections between a text and the content
of graphics and charts.

11341AFC437D4F22B2BD628F69B380FE.description:
Explain, interpret, and/or analyze the effect of text
organization, including headings, graphics, and
charts.

E46C2649586244328A9FAD81CCB637A6.description:
Identify, explain, compare, interpret, describe,
and/or analyze the sequence of steps in a list of
directions.

59A1986236B94D24A21847C2BB3921FE.description:
Identify, analyze, and evaluate the structure and
format of complex informational texts.

DD420D8DEBA94D509480FD4D4C8EA9CF.description:
Use appropriate strategies to
identify and analyze text
organization and structure in
literary nonfiction.

8D95A615940149F59332A5D728D608D1.description:
Explain, interpret, compare, describe, analyze, and/or evaluate point of view in
a variety of nonfiction:
• the point of view of the narrator as first person or third person point of view
• the impact of point of view on the meaning of a text as a whole

C8B1752243EA40B19C4CA46F5EB0CE45.description:
Explain, interpret, compare, describe, analyze, and/or evaluate tone, style,
and/or mood in a variety of nonfiction:
• the relationship between the tone, style, and/or mood and other components of a text
• how voice and choice of speaker (narrator) affect the mood, tone, and/or meaning of a text
• how diction, syntax, figurative language, sentence variety, etc., determine the author’s style

FE864223EB7643FB820F28FD1C7BE129.description: Explain, interpret, compare, describe, analyze, and/or evaluate theme in a variety of nonfiction: • the relationship between the theme and other components of a text • comparing and contrasting how major themes are developed across genres • the reflection of traditional and contemporary issues, themes, motifs, universal characters, and genres • the way in which a work of literature is related to the themes and issues of its historical period

09836EB4092D4CAC925F4A535CEE7424.description: Explain, interpret, compare, describe, analyze, and/or evaluate plot in a variety of nonfiction: Note: Plot may also be called action. • elements of the plot (e.g., exposition, conflict, rising action, climax, falling action, and/or resolution) • the relationship between elements of the plot and other components of a text • how the author structures plot to advance the action

D8721718303945719A99C493545308C0.description:
Explain, interpret, compare, describe, analyze, and/or evaluate setting in a
variety of nonfiction:
• the relationship between setting and other components of a text (character, plot, and other key literary elements)

C1526EF6E86948AA927FE78455F37866.description: Explain, interpret, compare, describe, analyze, and/or evaluate character in a variety of nonfiction: Note: Character may also be called narrator, speaker, or subject of a biography. • the actions, motives, dialogue, emotions/feelings, traits, and relationships between characters within nonfictional text • the relationship between characters and other components of a text • the development of complex characters and their roles and functions within a text

AB3FE48DCDAF48ED895438D66A012DCF.description:
Use appropriate
strategies to compare,
analyze, and evaluate
literary elements.

C1494AE965704F6A82040411925F3811.description:
Explain, interpret, compare, describe, analyze,
and/or evaluate connections between texts.

50A1C5B7E577460D8EC89A9449C94F8F.description:
Compare and evaluate the characteristics that
distinguish fiction from literary nonfiction.

1DCE603FFF0C474190C46AAB3CBEE507.description:
Analyze how literary form relates to and/or
influences meaning of a text.

2DC592BB21F74E079DB89FBFEE478F1E.description:
Use appropriate strategies to
compare, analyze, and evaluate
literary forms.

5B97D65B981E4035A2C7B92EAF8AA3F2.description:
Cite evidence from a text to support
generalizations.

F1D9C72A832F4173A67D32A88E41611A.description:
Make inferences and/or draw conclusions based on
analysis of a text.

D3A31F755A5B44B29B2779AD21011F7B.description:
Use appropriate strategies to
make and support interpretations
of literature.

C9560A8E574140F79445F4DE43D5A33C.description:
Analyze the interrelationships of ideas and events
in a text to determine how one idea or event may
interact and influence another.

04446A9E132642AD8CC54700994E92E9.description:
Summarize the key details and events of a
nonfictional text, in part or as a whole.

8384547A118349A09F1BD214C98FB7DF.description:
Identify and/or explain stated or implied main ideas
and relevant supporting details from a text.
Note: Items may target specific paragraphs.

28329DA9A1124EA980F4460C708EC3A0.description:
Use appropriate strategies to
comprehend literature during the
reading process.

B378F7172A064993A80504A49D177ECD.description: Draw conclusions about connotations of words.

50DFD8A9D6AE4B35B9DF4D926E12CB79.description:
Use context clues to determine or clarify the
meaning of unfamiliar, multiple‐meaning, or
ambiguous words.

CF13556C04B24F6CB52D0DF764114AB4.description:
Identify how the meaning of a word is changed
when an affix is added; identify the meaning of a
word with an affix from a text.

F419E02597354EDFA6A7906FEB1BED9C.description:
Identify and/or apply a synonym or antonym of a
word used in a text.

38BF3CB418BE4B2880B98B2720A733DB.description:
Use appropriate strategies to
determine and clarify meaning of
vocabulary in literature.

BFDCBA5A7BB14B6CAC0BD0D148E6D8ED.description:
Explain how an author’s use of key words or
phrases in text informs and influences the reader.

23F80B9ACF984DED8DBC6A2DE4868CC7.description:
Analyze, interpret, and evaluate how authors use
techniques and elements of nonfiction to
effectively communicate an idea or concept.

D50706D2A4834589A0CEB9038C5ECB6D.description:
Explain, describe, and/or analyze examples of a text
that support the author’s intended purpose.

846AEBC82A79456B9053568D6F0C9794.description:
Identify and/or analyze the author’s intended
purpose of a text.

A6D2F384B6C84DEBB478CF424BE93413.description:
Use appropriate strategies to
analyze an author’s purpose and
how it is achieved in literature.

DDFA0BE3574343FEBAF26289073B2397.description:
Identify and analyze how stage directions,
monologue, dialogue, soliloquy, and dialect support
dramatic script.

8F699D632DBC402FB17B5095D632CB4A.description:
Identify, explain, and analyze the structure of
poems and sound devices.

144DDA00491143EC8686EF4D021B4F73.description:
Identify, explain, interpret, describe, and/or analyze
the effects of personification, simile, metaphor,
hyperbole, satire, foreshadowing, flashback,
imagery, allegory, symbolism, dialect, allusion, and
irony in a text.

C76C3E85AB9E420B803FF27CC7B9BD82.description:
Use appropriate strategies to
identify and analyze literary
devices and patterns in literary
fiction.

E73CAE671708434795954FA69EF57277.description:
Interpret and analyze works from a variety of
genres for literary, historical, and/or cultural
significance.

FFD9BFC26FA44E5D90E402C269A75ADB.description:
Use appropriate strategies to
interpret and analyze the
universal significance of literary
fiction.

21A3B6C4662C40639293BB15002AFED0.description:
Explain, interpret, compare, describe, analyze, and/or evaluate point of
view in a variety of fiction:
• the point of view of the narrator as first person or third person point of view
• the impact of point of view on the meaning of a text as a whole

4F43FAAD6FF540B78C1D331D4333B0C1.description:
Explain, interpret, compare, describe, analyze, and/or evaluate tone,
style, and/or mood in a variety of fiction:
• the relationship between the tone, style, and/or mood and other components of a text
• how voice and choice of speaker (narrator) affect the mood, tone, and/or meaning of a text
• how diction, syntax, figurative language, sentence variety, etc., determine the author’s style

0D4FEBB6FE5A4B4A9F8A530DC9EE3BB0.description: Explain, interpret, compare, describe, analyze, and/or evaluate theme in a variety of fiction: • the relationship between the theme and other components of a text • comparing and contrasting how major themes are developed across genres • the reflection of traditional and contemporary issues, themes, motifs, universal characters, and genres • the way in which a work of literature is related to the themes and issues of its historical period

45EF89C9D6184C3FA9DE45DA1CFBF554.description: Explain, interpret, compare, describe, analyze, and/or evaluate plot in a variety of fiction: Note: Plot may also be called action. • elements of the plot (e.g., exposition, conflict, rising action, climax, falling action, and/or resolution) • the relationship between elements of the plot and other components of a text • how the author structures plot to advance the action

B26E2C8D8EDA4096AB74F11CD30E77C4.description:
Explain, interpret, compare, describe, analyze, and/or evaluate setting
in a variety of fiction:
• the relationship between setting and other components of a text (character, plot, and other key literary
elements)

A2B5FCA4C05B48769643FA2896123FC3.description: Explain, interpret, compare, describe, analyze, and/or evaluate character in a variety of fiction:Note: Character may also be called narrator or speaker.• the actions, motives, dialogue, emotions/feelings, traits, and relationships between characters within fictional text• the relationship between characters and other components of a text• the development of complex characters and their roles and functions within a text

78847F8F214E4BD1BB690107AF185A86.description:
Use appropriate strategies to
compare, analyze, and evaluate
literary elements.

B6E92CFC3F814E8FA471503B81D8B55B.description:
Compare and evaluate the characteristics that
distinguish narrative, poetry, and drama.

9B39956C05B6459E99B94630631985DC.description:
Explain, interpret, compare, describe, analyze,
and/or evaluate connections between texts.

F71F3804EF944E37A9FE58E21D6CD841.description:

Use appropriate strategies to

Cite evidence from a text to support

Make inferences and/or draw conclusions based on

CD847AA47BF643A7A128F1796991B519.description:
Use appropriate strategies to

Summarize the key details and events of a fictional
text, in part or as a whole.

Note: Items may target specific paragraphs.

Use appropriate strategies to
